abstract.para: This chapter tryes to give a short overview about the idea of trouble tickets in general and trouble ticket systems in detail. A short example shows the advantages of a ticket system.

sect1.title: What is a trouble ticket system, when do you need it?
sect1.para: The following example describes what a trouble ticket system is and how you can save time and mony if you use such a system in your company.

Lets imagine, that Max is a fabricant who produces video recorders. Because programing the video recorders is very complex, Max gets many mails from customers who need help with the devices. There are days, when Max has not enough time to anser all mails and so his customers has to be patient till they get an answer. Some customers don't want to wait that long and so they write another mail with the same question. All mails with the support requests are stored in only one inbox file, the requests are not sorted and the mails are answered with a normal mail program.

Some days the developers Joe and John have to help Max to answer the mails, because Max can't reply to all messages fast enough. Because Max, Joe and John use the same system with the same inbox file, they all access the same inbox. Joe and John don't know, that Max ofthen got two identical requests from the same desperated customer. So it happens, that Joe answers the first and John the second mail of the same customer, both with another helpfull hint how to solve the problem. That results in two different answers for the customer and Max does not know what John and Joe wrote. Max has no overview on the replys of Joe and John, he does not know all problems that the customer have with the video recorders, which problems occure very ofthen and how much time and money he has to spend for the customer support.

At a meeting a colleague tells Max about trouble ticket systems and that tey can solve the problems that Max has with his customer support. Max looks around in the internet and he decides to install the Open Ticket Request System (OTRS) on to a machine that can be reached via the web by his customers and his employees. Now the customer requests are not longer send to Max's private inbox but to the mail account that is used for OTRS. The ticket system connects to this mailbox and saves all requests in its database. For every new request the system generates a auto answer and sends it to the customer, so the customer knows, that his request has arrived and will be answered soon. OTRS generates an explicit identification for every request, the ticket number. Now the customers are happy, because they got a quick response to their requests, there is no need to send a secound message with the same question. Max, John and Joe can login into OTRS now with a simple web browser and answer the requests. Because the system locks a ticket which is answered, no message is edited two times.

Lets imagine, that Mr. Schmith makes a request to Max's company and his message is processed by OTRS. John answers this request shortly but Mr. Smith wants to know more and he replys again to Johns mail. Because John has other things to do, Max answers to Mr. Smith's message. The history function of OTRS makes it easy for Max to read the first message of Mr. Schmith and John's response, so he is able to write a longer and more detailed reply to Mr. Smith. Mr. Smith does not know, that two different people were involved in the communication process, he is only happy about the solution for his problem that arrived with Max's last reply.

Ofcourse this is only a short overview on the possibilities and features of trouble ticket systems. But if many customer requests (mails and phone calls) must be handled by different people, a ticket system can help to save working time and money. A ticket system helps you to structure your support or helpdesk envirorment and you can define workflow processes. The communication between customers and companies gets more transparent and that results in mor content customers and employees.

sect1.title: What is a trouble ticket?
sect1.para: A trouble ticket is a little bit like a medical report for a hospital patient. A new medical report is generated, if the patient visits the hospital the first time. All important data for the patient, personal data and facts about the medical problem, get inserted in the medical report. Every doctor adds information about the illness and the medication to the medical report so every one can get a quick and detailed overview about the problem of the patient. Every new doctor can quickliy see what's going on with the patient. If the illness is over and the patient is healthy again, the medical report gets closed and all information get archived.

Trouble ticket systems like OTRS handle trouble tickets like normal emails. The messages are saved in the system. If a customer sends a request, a new ticket is generated by the system, a new medical report is opened. The answer to this new ticket can be compared like an entry of a doctor into the medical report, a new anser of the customer like a change in the clinical picture of the patient. A ticket is finished, if an answer is send back to the customer or if the ticket is closed by the system. Sends a customer an answer to a already closed ticket, the ticket will be reopened and the new informations will be added. To keep the consistency of all data in the system, every ticket is stored and archived with all specific informations. Because tickets are handled like normal emails also attachments will be stored. Notes can be added as additional information to every email. All tickets are stored on the hard drive or in the database of the system, also the additional informations like notes, date, involved employees, needed working time for a ticket, e.g. All tickets can be sorted and it is possible to search through all data.
